11:15 am
BE11:15am

Just Eat has provided a 2016 full-year trading update this morning which is broadly in-line with our estimates. The company has reported full-year order growth of +42% on a reported basis (PGE: +44%) and +36% on a like-for-like basis (PGE: +35%). Investors may be disappointed that there are no upgrades to bfull-year estimates and the shares could well be punished for this.

BE11:16am

till bullish. Despite the lack of upgrades, we are still bullish on this stock and believe there is still significant upside to be realised. Just Eat will continue to take market share from the telephone, continue to make in-fill acquisitions that provide scale, enhance margins and boost earnings and continue to protect and extend its market leading position as leading aggregator models typically do. The management team is high quality and the acquisition of HungryHouse, if approved, will provide a catalyst for the shares. There is a lot to like about this stock.

BE11:16am

Significant upside yet to be realised. The stock trades on a FY17 EV/EBITDA multiple of 23.2x which justified given the company’s strong cash generation. The stock trades on a similar valuation multiple to other leading aggregator models despite generating a significantly higher rate of sales growth, thus the stock appears undervalued on a growth-adjusted basis. Our DCF analysis shows the shares to be worth 734p.

11:16 am
BE11:17am

And Jefferies.

BE11:17am

In-line Q416 order update from Just Eat, and having delivered five guidance upgrades in the last 20 months, likely to disappoint perhaps and the bears will home in on the deterioration in UK order growth. No real knocks to the thesis, just a reality check as the guidance upgrade conveyor belt comes to a stop. Expect to see modest EBITDA upside to FY16 guide still, the initial FY17 guide set to be somewhat damp...suspect stock treads water for a while...

Why are we writing today? Just Eat reported its FY16 order update this morning. Running into the print, our view had been that the Q416 ask implied by the £373m FY16 revenue guide delivered on 2 November was relatively modest, our model suggested UK Q416 YoY order growth of c.+25%, UK FY16 growth of +31% and Group FY16 at +42%.

Last heard 2 November, the Q316 update. Our key extractions:

Group orders +34% LfL, +34% on a reported basis, 33.3m orders in the quarter. Behind H1's +40% and 55%, respectively. Within that, UK order growth +28% against H1 +37%;
Mobile form factor continued to gain traction, 80% UK orders in Q3, of those 46% 'in app'; and
FY16 revenues expected to be c.£371m at CER, up from the £368m guide.

Expectations. Last year, we got reported order growth, like-for-like, and a brief comment around operations and investment. We got the same today.

The stock, somewhat directionless into the print. The JE stock has delivered in 2016, up 18% across the year vs the FTSE 250 +4%, but something of a hiatus since the Q316 order update, +4% since 2 November, in line with the FTSE 250, +4%.

The FY16 order update. A very short statement, less is more...

FY16 orders +42% on a reported basis, H116 +55%, Q316 +34%;
FY16 orders +36% on a LfL basis, H116 +40%, Q316 +34%;
The UK view, and perhaps we do obsess here, 2017 will certainly be the year in which International attracts more investor attention, FY16 +31%, H116 +37%, Q316 +28% and the implied Q416 +24%; and
David Buttress, CEO, commented, 'Just Eat's reported order growth puts us in a strong position to deliver full year results in line with our previous financial guidance. We enter 2017 with continuing confidence in the business.'

What does this mean for revenue? FY16 reported order growth the key metric, it drives revenues and to be honest, a few less moving parts versus the LfL order growth number. The Group and UK reported FY16 order growth numbers right on top of our model, we currently forecast £372.7m revenue, in line with the current guide £373m, and that a very likely outcome on 2 March.

In terms of EBITDA... We are ahead of company guidance here at £115.5m, the current range £109m - £111m, the model has stood us in good stead thus far, how Just Eat has flexed operational costs in H216 difficult to call though, bring on 2 March.

What comes next? JE reports FY16 numbers on 2 March.

​Closing thoughts... In-line, but the deteriorating UK order growth trend continues, a day for the bears we sense. We think two factors undermined UK growth in Q416, the hottest ever October and perhaps a more limited than expected impact on new customer acquisition from the rebranding exercise, Just Eat saw no impacts from Deliveroo, Uber et al.

BE11:17am

David Reynolds on the above, of course.

PM11:28am

Well done Mr Potts
So, a really good trading statement from Morrisons embracing profit upgrades; a welcome start to CY2017. We believe that there is more to come from Mr. Potts’ team, noting the headwinds outlined above, and so good year-on-year growth, a strengthening balance sheet with scope remaining for the possibility of shareholder friendly initiatives to come down the line and/or judicious expansion plans. Such an investment thesis, based upon unchanged FY2017 PTP forecasts for c18 months, ahead of today’s (10th January 2017) upgrades, should hardly be the stuff of such high shorting ratios to our minds. Hence, belated short closing could spike Morrison shares higher. HOUSE STOCK.

BE11:28am

(@DutchBrat: you make a good point. There weren't until you reminded me.)

BE11:29am

And here's Kantar via Jefferies .............

11:29 am
BE11:29am

A likely calendar impacted Kantar update outlined a buoyant Christmas period for the industry. Note that this year the Kantar P1 4-week update was up to 1 Jan 2017, compared with 3 Jan in 2016. We suspect that fewer, slow beginning of January trading days included this year would have boosted the overall reading. Juxtaposing today's MRW update (LFL +2.9%) with the LFL implied for the business by Kantar suggests that the calendar impact over this period could have been as high as 200bps. Note all the numbers quoted below are inclusive of this benefit, so our readers should focus on relative performance rather than absolute numbers.

BE11:29am

Discounters re-acceleration continues in a context of total industry growth of 3.4% (vs 0.3% for the trailing year). Discounters growth of 13.6% confirmed a further reacceleration in growth at German players, with the best relative trading momentum for 6 months. Quality players saw strong growth of 5.6% (vs 3.3% in the trailing year), but calendar benefits would be strongest here. Absolute growth at the UK majors was good at 1.6% (vs -1.3% in the trailing year), but we note that the lag to the overall market has accelerated to -1.9% (from -0.7% in the previous 12 weeks).

A winning Morrisons the major news today with cash sales growth implying LFL of c.5% over the period. This confirms the strongest period of outperformance relative to other UK majors for around 5 years (despite space dynamics still continuing to be negative). The successful introduction of SBO systems likely was an incremental driver in the period, and one which we expect to be enduring in nature.

ASDA back in the game? Cash sales growth of +0.5% is the first positive reading in over two years for the business. Most crucially ASDA appears to be sharply reducing its lag to other UK majors to -180bps (from -390bps in the previous year). It looks like improving in-store standards are allowing better traction with shoppers.

Tesco relative slow down confirmed as cash sales growth of 1.5% implies a small lag relative to the other majors. We calculated relative performance vs other majors to have slowed by c.600bps in the past three months. On today's evidence, the slow down in trading momentum between Q3 and Xmas may turn out to be sharper than we currently assume.

Sainsbury woes continue as cash sales of +0.9% suggest that our Q3 forecast LFL of -0.8% may leave some room for disappointment. A robust performance for Argos may prove a good offset. Non-food growth of +9.9% continues to be strongly ahead of food at -1.1%.

BE11:30am

Oh, there's Nielsen too ..........

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Why does the Nielsen data come out on the same day as the Kantar data? And, I think, the same day as Morgan Stanley's proprietary price tracker? Anyway, here's HSBC if you prefer Nielsen.

BE11:31am

A good Christmas underpins our expectations. Nielsen data confirm it has been a good Christmas but with trade weighted into the final week, as we discussed in What we expect, 6 January 2017. It was a "disloyal" Christmas with most retailers seeing increased visits and smaller baskets as customers shopped around. Tesco delivered good growth against tough comps. This growth is understated due to Tesco's Club Card Boost last year - we estimate its cash sales growth would be c70bp higher without Boost in the comparison. Morrisons looks to have done well with growth driven by increases in spend per visit, bucking the industry trend. ASDA had an improvement in trend. Sainsbury's saw its relative underperformance widen but may point to its shift to fewer promotions being a headwind. Nielsen suggest industry promotions have fallen to their lowest level in six years at 27% of sales, with Sainsbury lower still. This month's editorial focuses on the importance of momentum. In 2017 with a number of headwinds this will be more important than ever. Tesco remains well placed though, being the fastest growing retailer for most suppliers.

BE11:31am

Tesco (sales +1.9% market share 27.6%, flat). This is a good performance against tough comps. Last year was helped by Club Card boost and we believe cash sales are c70bps higher. This result underpins our c+1.5% Christmas LFL forecast and marks a 3rd good Christmas under the current management team. (NB: Tesco's trading statement due Thursday should also understate its real cash growth.)

Sainsbury's (sales -0.2%, market share 15.8%, down 30bp). Sainsbury's saw visit frequency increase but this was offset by basket size declines according to Nielsen. Its relatively large opening programme implies Sainsbury's saw LFL fall even more.

Morrisons (sales +0.5%, market share 10.3%, down 10bp). Morrisons traded well over Christmas as confirmed by its trading update this morning. Growth was supported by increases in spend per visit.

ASDA (sales -1.8%, market share 14.5%, down 50bp). ASDA's 12 week growth is still the lowest of the Big 4; this is an improvement in trend on a 1- and 2-year basis.

The Others: M&S (+3.5%) did well against particularly tough comps with 2-year growth over 10%. Co-Op (+3.2%) and Waitrose (+3.6%) also enjoyed good trading.

Discounters: Per yesterday's update from Aldi (+10%), they enjoyed a good Christmas, although Lidl at +5.8% continues to lag with, we suspect, negative LFLs.

PM11:34am

Currencies are driven much more by political developments than in the past.
This closer relationship between FX and politics means we can also use currency movements to inform us of the market’s view of political outcomes. In the UK, movements in GBP since the EU referendum in June tell us what type of Brexit the market is expecting. We use this relationship to create a “Brexometer” – a number between 0 and 100 telling us how hard a Brexit the market is expecting.
 If Brexit were never to happen, this would mean 0 on the Brexometer. We believe this is in line with GBP-USD trading around 1.55.
 The hardest Brexit would be 100 on the Brexometer. We believe this is in line with GBP-USD trading at 1.10 in the near term.
At the moment, with GBP-USD trading in the 1.20 to 1.25 range the FX market is telling us that it is expecting a relatively hard Brexit

BE11:37am

BE11:38am

There's also a bit of sellside around, such as Canaccord on Kaz.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Upgrade to BUY
Production increases to continue from late 2016 to 2018

In KAZ's 3Q16 production results, the company delivered substantially increased production levels as the Bozshakol mine continued its commissioning. Commercial production was declared from late October and we expect Bozshakol to be running near production capacity in the coming quarters. In December, KAZ also announced the commissioning of Aktogay some 3-6 months ahead of our forecasts. We forecast continued production growth at KAZ through 2018.

BE11:39am

Profit to significantly pick up from 2017

Despite our forecast for a strong yoy EBITDA recovery in 2016, we are forecasting continued strength in 2017, when we forecast EBITDA to double YoY. With our stronger copper price forecasts and also our continued production growth, we see 2017 as the second year where KAZ leads in EBITDA growth of all the copper companies we cover from London, but unlike 2016 we believe 2017 should include lower balance sheet risk.
Net debt to decrease from 2018

Beyond completion of the Bozshakol and Aktogay projects in 2017, we see 2018 as the first year of positive free cash flow for KAZ and also the first year of net debt reduction post project completion. While we do anticipate a modest decrease in gearing by year end 2017, CG forecasts 2018 as the first full year of net debt reduction.
Capex falls off from 2019, with a step up in free cash

The free cash story should further improve from 2019 as project capex (including deferred capex) starts to fall away after 2018. From 2019 we see a substantial increase in free cash generation and decreases in both net debt and gearing. We forecast 2019 as the first year where KAZ capex/OCF comes in below 50%.

BE11:39am

Most of our debt concerns addressed in late 2016

Over 2016 we highlighted the attractive growth profile of KAZ but the high risk balance sheet and debt maturity profile. In mid December, KAZ announced an additional debt facility of US$300mn with more flexible convenants and an extended maturity. At the same time, KAZ announced covenant waivers for the PXF and CAT facilities, with further negotiations to take place on maturities beyond year end 2016 reporting. These announcements address the vast majority of our debt profile issues, and re-align deleveraging with profit growth. We see this as a significant positive.
Upgrade to BUY rating, raising target to 475p

We have significantly increased our target on KAZ to reflect stronger production growth from Bozshakol (and potentially Aktogay), higher copper prices and a much improved cash generation profile to match revised maturities. Our revised target comes out to 475p (based on 2017 P/E, EV/EBITDA and NPV), over triple our previous 155p target. With over 20% potential upside to our target we upgrade to a BUY rating. While this upside is much more muted than KAZ equity gains in the past year, we still expect KAZ's growth story to continue into 2018.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

On the oilers, BMO has one of those epic 2017 preview notes out

BE11:40am

Positive Shell, downgrades BP.

Royal Dutch Shell PLC (RDSB:LSE): Last: 2,359, up 15 (+0.64%), High: 2,364, Low: 2,346, Volume: 986.47k
11:40 am
BP PLC (BP.:LSE): Last: 510.48, down 3.02 (-0.59%), High: 511.70, Low: 508.50, Volume: 6.32m
BE11:40am

Rejigs the smaller E&Ps a bit.

BE11:41am

In 2017, with we see oil in a $45-60/bbl trading range, and then ultimately improving into 2018. We see upside for Chevron (CVX), (FP-FP) and (RDSA) RDSB. We believe four sector themes will play out in 2017 as the focus shifts from dividend coverage and cash preservation back to project investment, resource capture, and reserve replacement.

The FOUR points include: 1 – The international integrateds are reaching an inflection point with the sector poised to deliver FCF of $80B in ’18 and $100B (including disposals). This is supported by reduced capex that is down 44% from its 2013 peak. 2 – Cost reduction and efficiency discipline is expected to continue in 2017 with divergence expected from the Independent E&Ps focused on unconventional who may start to experience cost re-inflation 3 – CVX remains the top pick within the sector. We see it benefitting from an increasing focus on short-cycle Permian growth and increasing productive capital as its delivers on its largely pre-invested projects 4 – We have upgraded RDS to OP while downgrading BP to Market Perform (530p). He sees less pressure on RDS achieving its greater than $30B disposals and future share buy-back programs. We forecast RDS to achieve 12.4% FCF and a 6.73% dividend yield in 2018.
· The sector is forecast to generate more than $80 billion organic FCF in 2018E, and we believe the industry is moving from dividend survival, to select investment in growth and resource sustenance.
· We reiterate CVX as preferred global major, increased TP: $140. Increasing productive capital, + FCF growth, div. growth. Permian asset offers competitive advantage.
· FP-FP remains one of our preferred European Integrateds… Reiterate OP and increased TP €47
· Upgraded RDS to Outperform (2550p), FCF and div yields, with improving ability and confidence to deliver on disposal buy back targets to 2020E.
· Downgraded BP to Market (530p), largely due to valuation. Trading inline with global peer group 16x P/E, 6.6x EV/DACF.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

· Over the next 2 years the International E&P sector offers better production growth and FCF yield than the US
· As a sector, there are 7 new projects vs 2 in 2016, production up 15%, with a $2bn swing in FCF
· This year the sector has continued its momentum. We think investors will have to be much more selective this year. We only have 8 outperforms out of 21 names, not many vs prior years and some of those lack the upside we saw 12 months ago.
· We would continue to focus on value but this year we think the market is going to reward those that are delivering into 2017, as well as those demonstrating de-risking of the most attractive projects within portfolios. We would chase this commodity bounce. We expect a pull-back in H2 and certain stocks will snap back quite quickly
· Our top picks are Kosmos Energy (KOS), Faroe Petroleum (FPM-LN), Hurricane Energy (HUR-LN) and Ophir Energy (OPHR-LN) as each still offer notable value and near-term opportunities to re-rate.
· We are reducing The Parkmead Group and EnQuest to Underperform (from Market Perform). Both struggle on valuation and EnQuest’s Balance sheet concerns aren’t behind them
· We are also reducing Tullow Oil and Ithaca Energy to Market Perform (from Outperform) after a strong recent performance and also Bowleven because we can’t see the catalysts in 2017.
· On the E&P side, TLW’s deal yesterday was done at ~12% discount rate/ $70/bbl long run oil price. It dosen’t give them as much cash up front, however they get carry past first oil for the 10% remaining interest.

BE11:51am

10 key themes for 2017 look broadly supportive: We enter 2017 with a glass half-full perspective noting: good macro momentum in Europe, an 86% US revenue per available room (RevPAR) correlation with investment spend, improving end markets, high occupancies, muted supply growth (even in the US vs history), limited risk from rising US inflation, potential consolidation, scope for lower US taxes and a UK backdrop helped by sterling weakness. We maintain our Outperform (OP) on International Hotels Group (IHG), which we view as high quality and low risk but also non-consensus. We upgrade Whitbread to OP given improving macro, self-help and valuation. Our thematic concern on Airbnb remains, and with Accor most exposed we maintain our Underperform (UP) rating and note concerns on valuation for its two divisions.

BE11:52am

■ Whitbread (upgrade to OP, TP 4550p from 4030p): We upgrade Whitbread to Outperform reflecting three key observations – 1) we see a return to positive hotel trading momentum and raise Feb-18E RevPAR to 3%; 2) the company's £150m cost-saving plan mitigates the risk from National Living Wage increases, and 3) valuation has rarely looked this inexpensive. With 19% potential upside to our new 4550p target price, we upgrade our rating to OP.
■ IHG (OP, TP 4330p from 3550p): IHG shares have underperformed US peers by 14% in Q4 and we see scope for potential 2017 surprises from cash returns, lower US taxes, an improving US macro and consolidation. Thus with 17% potential upside we maintain our Outperform rating.
■ Accor (UP, TP €34.8 from €30.5): Improved macro momentum drives a 9% 2017E EPS increase and our TP rises 14% to €34.8 per share as inputs are rolled forward. We see 2017 as being driven by valuation for both the disposal of HotelInvest and the ongoing multiple for HotelServices but we are sceptical on both and retain our Underperform rating.

BE12:01pm

Goldman upgrade.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

Vodafone offers above-average growth vs. the sector with +c.2%/+c.5% revenue/EBITDA CAGRs in FY17-20, on our estimates, benefiting from recent fixed-line investments improving its structural growth outlook. Our new cost-cutting analysis suggests VOD reduced underlying opex by 2% in the LTM. This raises our confidence in future delivery, contrary to investor scepticism. We model rising margins in FY18 as one-off items fall away. This self-help can also help relieve some of the NT pressure from Indian competition. Post 10% underperformance vs. the sector over the last 3m, valuation is compelling at c.9% CY18E FCF yield; up to Buy, from Neutral.

BE12:02pm

Catalyst

Our confidence in cost-cutting compounds our belief in Vodafone’s improving structural growth outlook, driving our FY18/19 EBITDA estimates +1%/3% vs. Bloomberg consensus. We also note ‘free’ optionality from potential European cable M&A (worth 10-40p per share (see page 14 for more detail) and potential market consolidation in India.

Valuation

VOD trades at a 10% discount to the sector on 2018E FCF yield and EV/EBITDA despite offering c.2 pp superior revenue/EBITDA CY17-20 CAGRs, on our estimates. After c.10% underperformance vs. SXKP over the last 3 months, our analysis suggests a relatively bearish scenario for India is now priced in. At our 12m price target (implies 24% upside), VOD would trade on 7% CY18E FCF yield, broadly in line with the sector, reflecting its superior growth and M&A optionality. Our revised 12-month ROIC-based PTs are 260p/$38 ADR (down from 275p/$41 ADR) as we make modest changes to our estimates, roll our valuation to CY18E, reflect completion of the VOD/LBTYA Dutch JV and update FX. Our PT includes c.£0.10/share of potential consolidation benefits based on our synergy-capture analysis of VOD merging its businesses with cable players.

BE12:03pm

You'll want that M&A bit as well, right?

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Liberty and Vodafone’s JV in the Netherlands has been approved by the EC, where Liberty has contributed its cable assets and Vodafone its mobile assets. We outline our analysis for the combination of the two businesses in the NL and our key assumptions on p17).

We believe similar synergies could be realized in the UK, DE and CEE between Vodafone and cable players. Assessing the capital structure considerations for any combination and indeed any merged entities in a respective country is difficult as there are numerous possibilities (based on leverage, tax etc). Therefore, we seek to assess what the current value of potential synergies could be for Vodafone based on the combination of Vodafone and cable assets in the UK, DE and CEE where there is a relevant overlap.

We consider cost synergies based on precedent transactions, notably Vodafone-KDG, Vodafone-ONO and Zon-Sonaecom, which targeted annual savings of 4%-8% of combined opex/capex.

BE12:04pm

Within our 12-month price target we now incorporate c.£0.10/share of potential consolidation benefits based on our synergy-capture analysis of Vodafone merging its businesses in UK/DE and CEE with cable players. This assumes Vodafone takes a 50% share of synergies at the midpoint of the combined opex/capex assumptions shown in Exhibit 23, and incorporate 30% of this potential value in our 12-month price target. We note uncertainty around capital structures, and potential regulatory risk around combining fixed and mobile assets.

Rome, January 10 - Italian police have smashed a cyber-espionage centre that for years collected sensitive data on politicians, public institutions and administrations, professional studios and top entrepreneurs, sources said Tuesday. The investigation, conducted by the postal police, led to the arrest of two people - a nuclear engineer and his sister.
The arrested pair are residents of London but are domiciled in Rome and are well known in the world of high finance, source said.
